text:
BRIAN KENNY: Welcome to
Managing Through Crisis,

a series featuring Harvard
Business School faculty
insights.

This series originally ran
from March through July of 2020

as the pandemic was
just taking off.

And now, two years
later, as the world

transitions to
endemic mode, we've

decided to bring the series
back to address what lies ahead.

My guest today is Karen
Mills, a former administrator

of the US Small
Business Administration

under President Obama and
a member of the president's
National Economic Council.

She's also the author of
Fintech, Small Business
and the American Dream.

And Karen was on this
very same show with me
just about two years ago, Karen.
So welcome back I guess?

KAREN MILLS: Well, I'm really
glad to be back talking to you.

And I will reflect that
the last time we spoke,

it was an entirely
different picture--
March 2020.
And now we're in March 2022.

And I will say we had no
idea about the two years

that we were going to go
through at that moment.
BRIAN KENNY: No, we didn't.

We shut this thing down in
July, thinking that maybe we
were almost at the end of it.

And, of course, here we
are, this time later.
But the issues have changed.

And I think what we
want to talk about now,

the reason that we
brought the series back,

was to think about
what lies ahead

as we transition to endemic
mode, whatever that turns out
to be.

And your knowledge of small
business and the leadership

that you provide there is
hugely important in this.

The last time that we
spoke, many, many people

reached out to us after
we posted the video.
They had more questions.

This was when PPP was coming up
and all of the other government
subsidies were coming up.

And a lot of that
stuff has seemed
to have dissipated over time.

But I think it's time for us
to revisit the whole topic

and think about kind of
where we go from here.

So let me just
start by asking you

to level set for our
viewers about the role

of small business
in the economy.
What does that look like?

How much of a percentage do
they make up of the US economy?

KAREN MILLS: Well, one thing
we learned from this pandemic

is how important small
business is to the economy.

And when I was in the White
House with President Obama,

in the 2009 crisis, we did
have a lot of conversation
about small business and jobs.

And what I kept saying
is half the people

who work in this country own
or work for a small business.

So I go to sleep worrying
about half of America's jobs.

And I think it was the
era of big business.

And people really didn't
understand the role

that small businesses
play in our employment.

Well, they certainly do now
because, as we look back

over these two years, when our
small businesses shut down,
unemployment just spiked.

And we saw that
small businesses are

very vulnerable because they
have very low cash buffers.

So this critical piece of our
economy was at tremendous risk.

And we did some unbelievable
things as a nation.

We came up with $700 billion
in PPP money, which saved
a huge part of our economy.

I think it really
was, and is proving

as we look at the numbers, to
be a critical stabilization
factor.
Now, it wasn't all pretty.

It was a bit of a
fast, messy process.

But it turns out that
many, many small businesses

were able to stay alive
and maintain their presence

and then reopen six months,
one year, sometime later,

and help us be in this moment
where we are seeing things more
in a positive vein.

BRIAN KENNY: I think that the
anecdotal evidence suggested

that this pandemic didn't
really affect white collar
workers that much.

I mean, if anything, people
found the flexibility
of working from home.

There were some silver
linings that came with it.

But for small
business, it seemed
like it was a different story.

Do you think that
they have suffered

more disproportionate
to larger firms?

KAREN MILLS: Well,
we know from the data

that small businesses
did suffer.

When I look at small
business job loss,

you can see it's much greater
than large business job loss.

And it recovers,
but more slowly.

And we also saw that
small business owners did
some really innovative things.
They hunkered down.
They went online.
They did delivery.

So the creativity and resilience
of small business owners
was very much on display.
But make no mistake about it.

This has been a very tough
time for small business owners.

And without these grants from
PPP and from the SBA disaster

loans, most of
them would not have
been able to make it through.

They just didn't have
the cash reserves.

BRIAN KENNY: We've heard a lot
about the Great Resignation.

That seems to be a
catchphrase these days.

And it would seem to
indicate that people

are kind of walking away
from career-type positions.

And I'm wondering if
you think that that's

going to fuel sort of a new wave
of entrepreneurship and people

starting out on their
own and trying to create
their own small businesses.

KAREN MILLS: Many things
changed in the pandemic.

But one of the most interesting
new trends that we are tracking

is the sharp rise in new
business applications.

I worried a lot
over time and worked

with many of our great
economists here at HBS--

Bill Kerr and Josh Lerner and
others-- on entrepreneurship.

And the declining rate
of entrepreneurship
was a topic of much discussion.

You know, entrepreneurship
is America's secret sauce.
It is the American dream.
You come to this country.
You start a business.
You provide for your family.

It's certainly my
family's story.

And this rate of
entrepreneurship

was declining over a very long
period of time, 30 years even.

And we were concerned that
it was harder and harder
to start a small business.

Well, that trend
has turned around.

Small business new starts are up
over 50% over the rate in 2019.

So who are all
these people and why
are they starting a business?

There are a lot of researchers
thinking about this.

But one of the things we
see in the Great Resignation
is that people have been home.

Maybe they had some
kind of payment,

whether it was PPP
or some of the grants

that came from the federal
government to tide people over.

They looked at some side
business or small idea
that they had.

And they decided to try to make
a go of it in these businesses.

We also see that sole
proprietors are up.

But there's a rise in
what we call high growth

or potential employer
businesses as well.

So if you look at the
landscape of small businesses,

there's 32 million
small businesses.

26 million of them have no
employees, this gig economy.

And this is the
fast-growing part.

So as it becomes easier
to start a small business,

you can have virtual
software as a services.

You don't have to hire,
necessarily, people.

You can take an
accounting service.
You can take a payroll service.

It becomes, I think, an
important positive trend

for the core entrepreneurial
engine of the United States,

and hopefully the
core innovation
engine and employment engine.

BRIAN KENNY: So, as we think
about this next wave that's

coming, and also
those businesses that

have been operating
throughout, you

spoke about how important
the stimulus was to keep
those businesses afloat.

What is government doing
now, or what should they

be doing, to help this next
wave of entrepreneurship thrive?

KAREN MILLS: One thing
that I watch very carefully

is access to capital and bank
loans to small business owners.

And we know that that is
a really critical part
of the small business economy.

And we also know it's a place
of great frictions and barriers,

that getting a small
business loan-- you
Xerox a pile of paperwork.
You walk down to the bank.

You wait three weeks
or three months.

And then the bank says no
and you go to the next bank.

It can be a very
difficult journey.

Well, a number of
things have happened.

First, when we had the
Great Recession in 2009,
banks froze their lending.

And they did that because
they had gotten overextended

in bad mortgages,
and they just didn't

have room on their
balance sheets
for small business lending.

And we had a devastating impact
on America's small businesses

because they
couldn't get capital.

At that time, when I
was running the SBA,
we did something pretty bold.

I remember having
a long discussion

with Larry Summers, who was
then the head of the National
Economic Council.

We raised our
guarantee rates to 90%.

And that meant a bank was only
responsible for 10% of the loan

and the federal government
guaranteed the rest.
And why did we do that?
Because nobody was lending.

And we got $30 billion worth of
SBA loans out in that next year

and 1,000 banks
back to SBA lending.

I call it the hockey
stick that did happen.

That taught me how important
access to capital was.

Now, the crisis we faced with
the pandemic was different.

And we had a different
set of solutions.

But in the recovery,
I was able to help

get legislation passed where
that 90% guarantee came back.

And what it did was let banks
who were looking at businesses

whose balance sheet had been
damaged in the recession--

they didn't have a good track
record over the last year

because they hadn't
even been open--

it allowed them to get a
loan with that guarantee

that the bank wanted to
give but couldn't quite
get the credit rating to give.

And that is helping
small businesses get

back to being able to
access the capital,

because when you reopen
your doors, you need money.
You need to buy inventory.
You need to pay employees.
So that's helping.

But I will say I looked at
the numbers this morning.

We are not yet
even close to being

back to the number of
businesses seeking capital

and the number of
loans being made.

So we have a ways to go to get
our small business economy back
going again.

BRIAN KENNY: Yeah,
more work to do there.

These are great insights,
as always, Karen.

I have just one more question
before we let you go.

And that would be, for those
entrepreneurs, those budding

entrepreneurs who
might be watching this,

small businesses
that are operating

that are watching this, is
there any word of advice

you would have for
them as they think

about how to navigate
this transition
to the next new normal?

KAREN MILLS: Well, for small
businesses across America,
I say, get back to business.

We hope very much
that this will be
a positive time in the economy.

And it is a time when
technology is transforming

the opportunity
for small business
owners and new entrepreneurs.

I mentioned that they can buy
all these different software
as services.

But there's one
last transformation

that I'm spending a
lot of time looking at.

And that is the
transformation in fintech,

in small business
lending from non-banks.

And it turns out that
this could change the game

in that painful loan
process I described.

One thing we did find
out in the pandemic

is that the PPP loans
were also allowed

to be given by these
fintechs and that fintechs

played an extraordinary
role in giving loans

to underserved
businesses, particularly
Black-owned businesses.

Over half of the loans
that went to Black-owned
businesses came from fintechs.

And I'm quoting a paper
by Sabrina Howell, who's
a terrific economist from NYU.

And this is really sort of
waking up everybody's thoughts

about how do you make
sure there's access
and opportunity for capital.

Because we need
small business owners

from every part of our country,
from every demographic.

We need women-owned businesses,
minority-owned businesses.

And we need this because this is
the path to the American dream.

This is how you can get
access and opportunity.

And we need to make sure those
doors are open, particularly
in terms of access to capital.

So I'm very hopeful
for the future because

of these new trends
in entrepreneurship,

and also because I think
transformational things can

happen with the world of
fintech and small business.

BRIAN KENNY: I love it-- an
optimistic note to end on.

Karen Mills, champion
for small business,

thanks for joining me on
Managing Through Crisis.
KAREN MILLS: Thank you, Brian.
